awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: DASI Track 1--Personal Space Weather Station
awd_abstract_narration:
This Distributed Arrays of Small Instruments (DASI) project will support the development of a network of Personal Space Weather Stations (PSWS).  The PSWS is a ground-based, modular, multi-instrument system capable of remote sensing the geospace system. This project is to develop a protoype of an integrated PSWSS which will initially consist of a radio receiver instrument, a ground magnetometer, and a central computer. The modular nature of the system will allow for the later addition of new instruments. This prototype is being developed in collaboration between multiple universities and the ham radio community through the Ham Radio Science Citizen Investigation (HamSCI) collective and the TAPR amateur radio engineering organization, who would eventually host instruments at their local sites. A primary goal of the PSWS project is to make it affordable to individuals. In this way, the PSWS network of instruments is easily expandable and can grow organically by engaging the general public. At the same time, stations can also be sited and managed by professional institutions, guaranteeing required coverage. 

The goal of the PSWS is to collect data on variety of phenomena - Traveling Ionospheric Disturbances and ionospheric absorption events, geomagnetic storms and substorms, magnetospheric ultra low frequency (ULF) pulsations, and geomagnetically-induced currents (GICs). TIDs exist over such large spatial scales that it is currently impossible to track them from source to dissipation. There is a significant lack of data on local effects of geomagnetic storms as well. The PSWS addresses this through the development of instrumentation that can easily be deployed internationally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to implement a group of small, software-controlled radio receivers that are inexpensive but still accurate enough to observe tiny changes in the observed frequency of the U.S. government’s frequency standard (WWV), in Boulder, CO. Since this frequency standard is atomically governed, any changes in the observed frequency are due to Doppler shift caused by movements of the part of the atmosphere that reflect (refract, actually) radio waves (the ionosphere, roughly 90 to 300 km altitude).

The University of Alabama’s role in the project was to (a) design and implement the software on the small radios to collect, store, and upload the spectrum of received signals and (b) stand up a web site to collect observed radio signals and make the data available to researchers for analysis. Both of these tasks were accomplished. The map (Map.png) shows the radios so far deployed in the U.S. (accessible at https://pswsnetwork.caps.ua.edu ). There are a few additional stations in Alaska, Northern Canada, and Europe.

To participate in data collection, a user signs up for a (free) account, creates one or more stations and adds instruments. The system provides a token that the user adds to their station to allow the station to connect to the server for uploading data. The hardware team provides a radio and small computer that the user configures using their token and other simple settings. Running stations upload one 24-hour observation per day.

The website provides several functions to allow users to see observations that have been uploaded, and filter these in a variety of ways (Observations.png).

When a user selects an observation, a plot (or multiple plots for stations monitoring multiple frequencies) is shown that displays the spectrum immediately around the WWV frequency, as well as the signal strength (Signal_Strength.png).

The user may click a button to download the plot or the entire observation for additional analysis on their own computer.

This system was successful in collecting and analyzing the ionospheric effects of the two eclipses in 2023 and 2024 (one annular and one full). In the image (S-Curve.png) we can see the characteristic “S-curve” captured by the station of W2NAF in Pennsylvania, where the shadow of the moon passes between WWV and the receiving station, creating a dip and then a rise in the received frequency of WWV. Remarkably, virtually all the stations active on that day observed a similar curve, even ones far away from the path of totality (e.g., in Canada, Florida and even in the Netherlands).

In more recent work, improved radios have been developed by the team; these allow collection of wider bandwidth and multiple frequency bands. With these, we can compare the effects of various drivers such as solar flares, coronal mass ejections, geomagnetic storms, and other phenomena on the ionosphere. We can see how it reacts, as well as study the effects of these drivers on radio propagation. In more recent work, scientists have used the data collected by the PSWS system to calculate how Traveling Ionospheric Disturbances (TIDs) move across the continent with an eye toward better understanding what causes these waves in plasma density. We believe that a denser network of receivers (as planned for Phase II) will enable further discoveries in geophysics and long-distance radio propagation, as well as expanding our understanding of the ionosphere itself.
